(c) Write the negation of the following sentence without having the first word of the sentence being Not. Not every state has an sales tax.
Solution: Some state has no sales tax.

2. (a) Suppose q is an integer. Prove by induction that if n\geq 1, \left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & q \\ 0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right)^n=\left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & n\cdot q \\ 0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right).
Solution: Basis: The equation is true by the definition of the first power of a matrix for n=1.
Induction: Assume the equation is true for some n\geq 1. Then

p.m: \left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & q \\ 0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right)^{n+1}=\left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & q \\ 0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right)^n\left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & q \\ 0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right)\text{ }\text{by} \text{the} \text{definition} \text{of} \text{exponentiation}\\ \\ \text{$\quad $ }=\left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & n\cdot q \\ 0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right)\left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & q \\ 0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right)\text{ }\text{by} \text{the} \text{induction} \text{hypothesis}\\ \\ \text{$\quad $ }=\left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & q+n\cdot q \\ 0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right)\\ \\ \text{$\quad $ }=\left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & (n+1)\cdot q \\ 0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right)

3. (a) Recall that the relation divides on the integers is defined by \quad \quad a divides b if and only if (\exists k)_{\mathbb {Z}}(a\cdot k = b).\quad We abbreviate a divides b to a|b. Prove the implication (a|b ) \land (b|c)\text{ }\Rightarrow \text{ }a|c. Hint: You need to use two k's in the proof.
Solution: \quad \quad a\left|b \Rightarrow a k_1\right.=b for some integer k_1
\quad and b\left|c\text{ }\Rightarrow b k_2\right.=c for some integer k_2

(b) Let n be a positive integer greater than 1. Recall that \equiv_n is a relation the integers defined by\quad \quad a \equiv_nb if and only if (\exists k)_{\mathbb {Z}}(a-b=n\cdot k) Prove the implication a\equiv_nb\text{ }\Rightarrow \text{ }b\equiv_na
Solution: \quad \quad \quad a\equiv_nb\text{ }\Rightarrow \text{ }a-b = n k\text{ }\text{for} \text{some} \text{integer} k\\ \\ \quad \Rightarrow b-a = n(-k)\\ \\ \quad \Rightarrow b\equiv_na
